positive.review:
This isn’t Final Fantasy, it's DMC with a Final Fantasy veneer. While its heart isn't the epic world, it does have all the chess pieces. Chocobos. Crystals and Magic and The Empire. A moogle. Eikons/Eidolons/Espers/Summons. I can't say that it's not wearing Final Fantasy's costume well, but it's still lacking compared to entries including and before XIV: A Realm Reborn.

You can feel the bones of a great world under the surface, but the game never actually lets you live in it. It wants to show you a legend instead of letting you take part in one. Everything that used to make the series feel like a sprawling fable has been boiled down to a straight line with a fireworks show at the end.

Exploration doesn’t matter because the world doesn’t trust you with anything. Chests are meaningless, gear is flavor text, and sidequests mostly exist to remind you how sad everyone is while handing you rewards that don’t change a thing. There’s no sense of discovery, no delight in wandering off the beaten path, no moment where curiosity pays off. The game isn't built for players, it’s built for viewers.

And the party system? It’s gone in everything but name. Characters orbit you like set pieces, occasionally shouting flavor lines while you do all the real work. It’s gorgeous, the combat feels good, and the presentation is immaculate, but it’s hollow in the places that used to matter. It’s a stage missing its ensemble, a story missing its world, a Final Fantasy missing its fantasy.

FF16 is a well-made action game, sometimes even a thrilling one, but it’s not the next chapter in the series I grew up with. It’s something else wearing the coat, hoping the logo on the box will convince you otherwise. If you want spectacle, you’ll get it. If you want a world that feels alive, a story you inhabit, or an epic that rewards your curiosity the way this series once did, you’re going to feel the absence like a missing limb.

This game, for all intents and purposes, is good. Great, even. It's absolutely worth playing, and its common criticisms are either overblown or technically correct but avoidable/literally just inconsequential.

Here's the longer review. No spoilers.

FF16 is a game that spends around 10-15% of its runtime being literally the coolest game ever made. It divvies up the remaining ~90% being either a very good literal movie (seriously, there are some long cutscenes) or a questionable "open-world" game clearly designed by MMO-makers. Sidequests are essentially are "Go here, do thing," and while I quite like simple MMO-type quest design, even I stopped really doing them around the 70% mark, despite the fact that the stories they tell are genuinely really, really good.

The story of this game is great, in my opinion, and given how divisive it is I don't really think I can give it a blanket "do recommend" versus "don't recommend." It gets better the more you chew on it and its themes alongside HOW those themes are represented. It's a solid ride throughout, with some great emotional highs and never really any low points. Again, while I liked it, it's a story that appeals to my sensibilities, and it DOES take a pretty hard swerve in the back half that might sting if you live and breathe for the political shenanigans of the first half. I will say that despite how much I like the story, its execution and pacing does have issues. There's so many moments in the game where it randomly decides to slow things down and have you do errands, and while these moments are there so that you experience some worldbuilding/character interaction, it really doesn't feel that good to go from an insane visual spectacle of a kaiju battle to... needing to go fix a ship.

Gameplay-wise, it's also quite good. Solid if simplified DMC-inspired combat (with a smattering of Witch Time) where the bulk of your options come from the six (technically nine) cooldown-based abilities you choose to use in combat. Unlike DMC where you're mostly interweaving combo attacks with arcade-style inputs, this game has a grand total of one weapon, and to go with it, two weapon strings (one in the air, one on the ground) and basically no other options. It never really gets annoying, but combat when your Eikon abilities are on cooldown can get a bit boring because you really don't have many options when it comes to pure melee. Lots of criticisms come from players who say that there are optimal abilities to use and that they make every battle the same, and while it's true that you can optimize for damage, you can also do that in any DMC game by spamming Stinger over and over. Suffice to say that while you CAN treat every fight as a QTE to set up big damage (and honestly, with some of the pre-final boss mob encounters, you'd be hard-pressed not to), it's still up to you to try and be stylish. However, I do somewhat agree that most Eikon skills are kind of nothingburgers, sometimes visually but usually statistically. It feels really bad to use a skill that you think looks cooler only to find that it does way less damage or has way less utility than another skill, mainly because you only get 6 ability slots and the ability cooldowns are so long that it's only natural to want to maximize them.

Hilariously, none of the Eikons nor their skills really feel good to use when you first get them (aside from literally the first two, and that's because their Eikonic Feats are basically part of your basic combat skills rather than their own actual abilities). I honestly kind of suspect that the devs spent so long making their own game that they'd gotten used to the Eikons and not really realized that they all feel strange to use off the bat. 

When it comes to subsystems, you can customize your ability loadout, but aside from that... there's basically no RPG under the hood (which, may I say, is a flaw, but not the one people are making it out to be). The game gives you so many fucking crafting materials that you can't even use because there's nothing really to craft them with. You get 3 accessory slots that range from complete jokes of items (most of them) to actually pretty game-changing ones (though the majority of these are in the DLC). Weapons and armor don't do anything. At all. They make number bigger. Shining glowing items on the ground are basically useless because they're more crafting materials that you CAN'T USE. It's also why the world isn't worth exploring in the least -- it's pretty, sure, but there's nothing in it for you besides finding some neat environmental details and probably another 3 chunks of Wyrrite you have nothing to craft with. It is genuinely beyond me what the point of this gear system was. The game also has character stats that you cannot affect in any way beyond levelling up. The only time this ever comes into play is if you try taking on some Hunts (miniboss bounties) that are above your current paygrade, where a 15-level difference essentially puts the fight onto Nightmare mode. They're sometimes welcome challenges, but because the game has you on a level curve (XP grinding is a monumental waste of time), most of that challenge will be gone if you choose to just come back a couple hours later into the game.

The game is a visual masterpiece, enough said. The Eikon bosses are the best setpieces in any video game I've ever played, to say nothing of the regular story bosses (and even some minibosses!). If there's anything you'd get this game for, it's these absolute masterpieces. In addition, basically every area of the game is eye candy and the game does a really good job of conveying atmosphere no matter where you are. Same goes for music. The game's music is very good (when it wants to be) and immersive. Enough said, really.

In all, FF16 is a great game that is worth playing, though not without valid criticism of its many flaws (I feel a need to say that not being a turn-based Final Fantasy is decidedly NOT a flaw). Mindblowingly spectacular at times and unbelievably menial at others, I believe that this game's mountainous highs manage to shine so bright that some of its cavernous lows are entirely made up for.

FFXVI is a gorgeous game. It is a visual spectacle. The characters, environments, audio design: all of it combine to give a weighty epic opera-tic feel that is FINAL FANTASY. The world building is also a great fave of mine, a blend of vaguely european feudal kingdoms liberally interspersed with now standard FF tropes like chocobos and eikons. I feel immersed in a realm where men are real men, carving their own path. Who doesn't daydream of being some noble scion, with the hand of destiny upon you? 

On the aspect of gameplay, combat is fluid, and forgiving. I'm sure battles will get tougher, but the game's prologue (which is about 2 hrs!) does a really good job to ease you into the controls and the plot itself. The english voice acting is EXCELLENT, and really sells the idea of a medieval soldier. 

FFXVI is a retelling of the ancient stories: the knight on a quest, the vengeful son who lived, the vagabond who awakens to his destiny... none of it is really new, but we love it all the same when true masters weave the tale.

This game will forever hold a special place in my heart for teaching me how to hope again, the themes within this game have been essential towards helping me out of the trap of despair and depression life has thrown me into.  

I resonate with this game because of how it tackles oppression, being a trans individual I connected with the struggles bearers go through and I love how the game tackles oppression in a realistic way but also offers glimpses of hope. 

Personally one favourite quote of mine from this game is: "I want to create a world where you're judged on who you are, and not what you are. But the world isn't ready for that yet, so until it is I use the power I've been given to show people there is hope.".

I embodied that quote into my mentality towards life, it used to make me mad depressed that I can't erase all the discrimination minority groups are subjected to. But what I am able to do is do what is within my power to show other trans individuals that there is hope, this was the driving force that shifted me from a mentality of wanting to inflict harm back onto my oppressors to wanting to help out as many trans individuals I can. Like Clive, I worked from shifting away from a heart of hate to a heart of love.  

Until the world is ready to accept trans individuals fully, what we can do is keep on using our power to make sure other trans individuals maintain a heart of hope instead of despair. I resonated with Clive so much in this regard that I actually made it my dream goal to do exactly that, if I can do my best to give hope to as many trans individuals as possible, I'd be happy with what I've done in my life. 

I love FF16's story telling, since even though I'm saying this specifically about trans people. All of what I've said can be applied to any oppressed group, which is why I consider FF16's story to be truly beautiful. 

I know a lot of people don't like FF16 due to issues the game has or because it strays away from turn based combat, but from a subjective stand point it changed who I am as an individual. Which I will always thank the FF16 dev team for. This review is more about my personal impact rather then trying to put up an argument that if FF16 is good or not, if you happen to go through similar mental struggles I think giving this game a shot might help. 

I've been playing FF16 while in severe depression and some of the story beats really hit me deep. It's better help me understand how depression can try to win us over and how to recognise those patterns, which in turn teaches me how to overcome it. 

Probably one other thing I really loved in this game is it just teaches you that being a softy around your friends isn't cringe, I think society has conditioned us to not be emotional around our friends or acknowledge how much of an impact they have on us because it's cringe.  

I think one of the reasons the game had that type of impact on me, is because I see Clive as this super overpowered badass individual who I think is cool as fuck. So when I see this guy being kind and soft to his friends, I believe that is being cool as fuck. So now I'm growing softer to my friends since I think it's cool as fuck xD 

Which in turn has also helps me better to start feeling emotions again, I know there was a shifting point where I started properly appreciating my friends, learning to better share my interests, my emotions, acknowledging how they're integral to my happiness. TBH, I think it all originally started with this game.

On my 6th playthrough to get 100% completion across multiple platforms.

Good story, great acting, beautiful environments, absolutely amazing character development and lore, beautiful music, and a near-perfect love letter to long-time Final Fantasy fans who enjoy trying new gameplay experiments with each new installment in the FF franchise.

Battle system could use some polish, but for being the worst thing about the game, it was surprisingly fun with some customization; The cutscene-type abilities really slowed down the pace of the battle, as well as some of the Eikon Feats doing the same, so with the right ability setup, the battle system feels much more intuitive, responsive, fast, and fun. My favorite Eikon to use is Titan equipped with two counter-abilities--there's something about landing a three hit Titanic Block counter or Raging Fists counter that just feels so good! My least favorite Eikons to use are Ramuh and Bahamut because their pausing-type abilities feel so out of place in an action-focused game.

Overall, if you can get around the quirks of the battle system, the game is well polished gem overall. I hope they either make a sequel/prequel or add more DLC after the two that were already released (Medicine Girl, you must have more of a purpose, don't you...)

It's a very good entry into Final Fantasy, but it's not without its problems. I liked it a lot more than FF15. I would never pay full price for the experience, but if it's on sale, it'll be worth your money.

Pros:
1) Very fun and customizable real-time combat system.
2) Extremely impressive set-piece battles that are beautiful to look at.
3) The prologue and Act 1 are well worth the price of admission. 
4) Side quests are designed to meaningfully build upon the world lore.

Cons:
1) Exploration and crafting is extremely unrewarding.
2) Money is worthless.
3) Itemization very little impact on play outside of the "accessibility" items you start the game with.
4) Acts 2 and 3 are riddled with pacing issues that severely undermine the narrative.
5) Side quest structure, aside from narrative, is extremely repetitive. Go to x, talk to y, fight z. Maybe gather a.

To me it feels like the game got budget-rushed bigtime. They spent the first 3 years working on the graphics, sound, and combat, then the next 3 months perfecting the combat, then the next 3 weeks writing the entire plot and characters, the next 3 days designing the map, the next 3 hours designing inventory/items/weapons, and the next 3 minutes putting it all together.

Pros:
The game is quite stable. No issues to report.
The graphics are great.
The sound is great.
The re-use of traditional elemental names like Ifrit, Shiva, Bahamut, and Ultima is very welcome. 
The combat is REALLY great, as in an action game melee non RPG kind of a way. Visually stunning, without any complicated gameplay mechanics.
The plot could have been GREAT, it's still good, but there's SO much room for it to be better. So many unexplored rabbit holes throughout.
Works great on a MS-Xbox controller.

Seriously though, I didn't buy this game for the combat but they really nailed this aspect of the game.

Cons:

FF4 had 10 times better character arcs than this. I teared up when Palom and Porum did what they did, all 30 pixels of them. 
There is NO depth to these characters whatsoever by comparison.

There's literally no point to most of the inventory. It just sits there.
I don't even need to sell that inventory because there's hardly anything to buy with all the money you accumulate.

Combat is shallow and for the whole of your first run you are basically in a long tutorial and wont have access to everything until after your first run and both DLC are completed then you start NG+ Final Fantasy mode, which is where the real game begins. As much as I love DMC, this type of combat, though better than FF15, doesn't fit in this genre. Not only are you going to do a 50-60 hour tutorial just to unlock the full combat system, but it then just becomes about slowing down time/stagger using abilities that are on a cooldown. It's pretty much no combat and just using a few abilities off cooldown to wipe a boss in a single stagger. In the end, the pros heavily outweigh the cons. FFXVI offers a stunning journey and an adrenaline rush that you won't soon forget. Highly recommended.

[h1][b]After >100hrs and 100% achievements, I feel I have a grasp on just about everything FFXVI has to offer, and I don't recommend it.


↓TLDR FOUND BELOW.↓[/b][/h1]


[h1][b][u]THE GOOD[/u][/b][h1]
[*] The last DLC "The Rising Tide" is what I wished the main story was. A simple narrative with a simple message, executed well, that doesn't overstay its welcome.

[*] Oddly enough I think the strongest aspect of FFXVI is its User Interface. SE must have thought so too because you can see many of the UI elements introduced in this game in the new FFT Remaster.


[h1][b][u]THE MID[/u][/b][h1]
[h2][b]VOICE ACTING[/b][/h2]
[*] It's always aggravating when throwaway NPCs have better performances than the main characters, and this game is no exception. I didn't like Ben Starr (Clive Rosfield) or Susannah Fielding (Jill Warrick)'s performances, as the prior felt comically over-dramatic and sullen, and the latter felt comically apathetic and dry. I have a feeling this is due to direction and not acting talent though, especially after playing Expedition 33 and seeing Ben Starr play Verso. That being said there are one or two moments in FFXVI that stuck out to me where Starr's delivery was exceptional, and many people including me appreciate his passion for JRPGs. Ralph Ineson as [spoiler]Cid[/spoiler] was easily my favorite performance, [spoiler]I really wish we had more time with his character[/spoiler].

[h2][b]MUSIC[/b][/h2]
[*] Of course this is subjective, but I think Masayoshi Soken's soundtrack for FFXVI is the same as FFXIV: A very functional, serviceable OST with some amazing stand-out tracks.


[h1][b][u]THE BAD[/u][/b][h1]
[h2][b]NARRATIVE[/b][/h2]
[*] I think the first act has a compelling setup, and the second act had me on the edge of my seat wondering how some of the biggest major conflicts would resolve. The game hits its peak at the end of act 2. There's a boss fight with some ridiculous over-the-top spectacle (in a good way), and all of the main character conflicts that I cared about were resolved. 

Then the game keeps going. 
And going. 
And going.

To say the final act is drawn out is a criminal understatement. Every scene is stretched out to its limit, information is constantly repeated because the audience can't be trusted to pay attention, and characters talk in circles. Any scene with [spoiler]Barnabas Tharmr aka Odin[/spoiler] made me want to blow my brains out, and they take up pretty much the entire third act. I really can't stress enough how drawn out the finale of this game is.

I hate to use this word, but FFXVI's narrative is [b]pretentious.[/b] It acts as though it is telling the most grandiose, nuanced, deeply compelling story imaginable, when in reality it is the same gnostic slop we have been presented with for decades at this point. Having [spoiler]"god" actually be a lesser malevolent force[/spoiler] is nothing new to the FF franchise, in fact it's the plot of just about every game in the series. But man if FFXVI doesn't act like this is the first time it's ever been done, and that you should be in awe for it being so avant-garde. For being such a contrived plot, you'd think they would've been able to execute it with precision at least, but FFXVI falls short here as well. The point has been made but my feelings are only so strong because acts 1 and 2 were so promising, which made me feel even more disappointed with the lackluster finale that ultimately ended up being a huge waste of time.

[h2][b]GAMEPLAY[/b][/h2]
[*] Speaking of a huge waste of time, FFXVI's combat is repetitive and boring. You spam basic attacks until your abilities are ready, use said abilities, rinse and repeat for [b]100 HOURS[/b]. Every single enemy is a damage sponge. The combat does actually have a lot of depth in terms of how you can chain combos and abilities, but you are never incentivized to explore this depth, as you will ultimately end up doing less damage than if you had just done the aforementioned "spam square until abilities are off cooldown." I think this repetitiveness could have been remedied by a DMC-style "grading" system that encourages players to actually use combos. Maybe give them a damage boost if combos are executed properly, then it feels like the enemies are sponges for a reason other than to waste your time.


[h1][b][u]TLDR[/u]/FINAL THOUGHTS[/b][h1]
[*] [b]TLDR: [/b]Play something else that interests you and respects your time more. Although FFXVI has some stand-out moments, I cannot recommend it due to its needlessly long playtime, disappointing final act and repetitive gameplay. 

[*] I'm screaming into the void saying this, but please stop making 30-40 hour RPGs 70-100 hours with pointless filler. I miss when FF games were 30-40 hours and told a succinct, compelling story with great characters that stayed with you long after the credits rolled.

While I wasn't expecting FF16 to reach the storytelling highs of Shadowbringers or Endwalker, I at least expected it to be fun and tell a good story. The devs somehow managed to fail at both. Horribly.

People describe this game's story as "FF meets Game of Thrones" and that's only true on a surface level. It's dark and gritty with a plot that focuses heavily on politics and intrigue with the occasional kaiju battle mixed in. But the writing fails horribly at making any of it actually interesting or meaningful. Characters are paper thin, with Jill, the female lead, in particular being quite possibly the blandest FF character I've ever seen. Her sole character trait is "Clive's girlfriend" and has so little personality or agency, she may as well just be another accessory hanging off of Clive's belt. The political intrigue is also mostly set dressing, to give Clive a reason to revisit the same brown/grey town for the 10th time, but never actually give the player a reason to care about the wider world or the people in it. Cutscenes and dialogues are presented with bare bones, MMO-style cinematography that works fine for games like FF14 but has no business in a modern single-player RPG. The plot is also predictable as hell, embracing every "dark fantasy" trope in existence with little in the way of surprises or twists. You've seen this story a million times before.

The quest design ranges from boring fetch quests to main storyline quests that involve watching a dozen or so roundabout dialogue scenes before being sent down a linear corridor where you fight a group of the same reskinned enemies with the same shallow combat mechanics.

The combat system itself is pitifully bland at first, then gets fun after you unlock a few more abilities, then gets bland again once you realise those abilities are all flash and no substance. You can easily win any fight by just dodging and hitting things with your sword. The Eikon fights have potential at first, but they feel so janky to control and the fights drag on so long that they don't feel anywhere near as powerful and badass as they should. Not to mention most of them play out more like on-rails shooters and QTE fests than an actual combat system.

Even the character and world design is a letdown. Final Fantasy has a reputation for crafting beautiful worlds that you want to get lost in, with memorable characters whose designs spark the imagination. But I think whoever was in charge of the art in this game forgot what franchise this is, because every environment you visit has the same washed out, grey/brown color palette. Character designs are equally as bland. Clive, for some reason, is the only character who even remotely looks like what you'd expect a FF character to look like. But because everyone else around him looks so painfully drab, he ends up looking like a cosplayer who got sent back in time. It's impossible to take him seriously. And the game really, really, wants you to take him seriously.

If there's one positive, it's in the sound department. The voice acting and music are top notch, but unfortunately neither can save an otherwise excruciatingly dull game.

If I could get a refund, I would.

A GPU-mangling hack n' slash, lovingly infused with the trademark village-burning, past-forgetting, chicken-riding, god-slaying, compound-word-molesting, particle-effect-ranching genre guff, only this time it thinks it's dark Western fantasy, which means your stock cast of paper-thin Vivienne Westwood models grumble their shounen angst in a zoo of British accents, and the story is a sheltered Japanese kid's attempt at Glen Cook or Steven Erikson, the result being a muddle of grimderp that basically fails to tell a proper, joined-up tale, even to the low standards of the series, and relies on an in-game wiki to fill you in.

The fighting seems built primarily to look good, and yes, it's facemelting, with set-pieces that rival/arguably impinge upon the copyright of Hollywood movies, but this cart-before-the-horse design has resulted in fight mechanics so open that they can feel shapeless, so that it doesn't really know the kind of mechanics it wants, only it wants them to look good. The addition of items that change combat from open-ended DMC to arcadey Arkham, to RPG command buttons and auto-dodging, has been celebrated as progress for accessibility and customisability, but criticised as a step backwards in standards of difficulty in video games, and for splitting the (traditionally singular) experience of a FF into a bunch of different experiences.

I think the devs created this problem on their own. RPGs balance themselves, grind enough and anyone can beat anything (that's the promise of RPGs), but action games have hard, mechanical ceilings (that's the promise of action games). If it was a traditional FF, the items wouldn't be needed. If it was an action game outside the main franchise line, the items wouldn't be needed. But because it's this spectacle-first chimera, the devs had to hack their action game into an RPG game, just to please their main customers.

For what it's worth, I think they made the right decision putting the items in, but it's a band-aid on the backwards decision to turn FF into stroke-inducing fight scenes, and hang the mechanics.

I am writing this after reaching the credits on the Action Focused difficulty and completing all available sidequests, all hunts and a few of the time trials. I do not have the DLC.
This is a linear action game. If you tried the demo, that includes the first few hours of the full game and another early stage. In my opinion, the early game is its strongest part. One of my favorite boss battles happens at the first crystal you visit. After that, intrigue gradually declines, and the last 20 hours are such a slog. You come to realize there are entire towns and cities that only exist in cutscenes, and visiting several places deletes them from relevance in the rest of the game. Eventually the game just does away with having people in its later areas (not without reason, but the reason doesn't really make it worth it). If you were drawn in by the notes of a Game of Thrones-style plot, well, it's nice while it's around.
Combat was generally easy for me and had a hard time holding my interest. With little variation, Clive can disrupt what small enemies are doing and knock them down with the basic combo alone. Bigger enemies are fought by staggering them and inputting all of your skills at them. The bestiary is quite small, with variety coming from giving old enemies new tricks. I had something like 7 or 8 game overs, including a few deaths where I was trying to fight enemies just by countering everything. You get a decent drip of new techniques to try, but once I had more skills than slots, I just dumped some of my huge AP pool into maxing the fastest ones to use. There were glimmers of interesting encounter design around - I enjoyed fighting Dread Comet and Necrophobe, for instance.
This game does have many nice-looking places and vistas. Graphically, it generally seemed quite strong, and there are only a few quest-related conversations where I noticed something looking quite bad, like odd lighting on the characters.
Music is okay. Big moments have appropriately big compositions. There's a cataclysmic event that happens during the story, after which some weaker tracks really wear out their welcome.
Sidequest quality varies widely. The average sidequest is, someone tells you about a group of easy enemies and you fight them for an item, or you learn the location of an item but there happens to be a group of easy enemies there. A few late-game quests float an idea or two that might have gotten deeper exploration in a more interesting game.
Overall, I could see some people enjoying their way slashing through this game just to see what's here, but I'd suggest waiting for a sale. I think it takes some fortitude to stick this whole game out without getting too bored.

[h1][b]After >100hrs and 100% achievements, I feel I have a grasp on just about everything FFXVI has to offer, and I don't recommend it.


↓TLDR FOUND BELOW.↓[/b][/h1]


[h1][b][u]THE GOOD[/u][/b][h1]
[*] The last DLC "The Rising Tide" is what I wished the main story was. A simple narrative with a simple message, executed well, that doesn't overstay its welcome.

[*] Oddly enough I think the strongest aspect of FFXVI is its User Interface. SE must have thought so too because you can see many of the UI elements introduced in this game in the new FFT Remaster.


[h1][b][u]THE MID[/u][/b][h1]
[h2][b]VOICE ACTING[/b][/h2]
[*] It's always aggravating when throwaway NPCs have better performances than the main characters, and this game is no exception. I didn't like Ben Starr (Clive Rosfield) or Susannah Fielding (Jill Warrick)'s performances, as the prior felt comically over-dramatic and sullen, and the latter felt comically apathetic and dry. I have a feeling this is due to direction and not acting talent though, especially after playing Expedition 33 and seeing Ben Starr play Verso. That being said there are one or two moments in FFXVI that stuck out to me where Starr's delivery was exceptional, and many people including me appreciate his passion for JRPGs. Ralph Ineson as [spoiler]Cid[/spoiler] was easily my favorite performance, [spoiler]I really wish we had more time with his character[/spoiler].

[h2][b]MUSIC[/b][/h2]
[*] Of course this is subjective, but I think Masayoshi Soken's soundtrack for FFXVI is the same as FFXIV: A very functional, serviceable OST with some amazing stand-out tracks.


[h1][b][u]THE BAD[/u][/b][h1]
[h2][b]NARRATIVE[/b][/h2]
[*] I think the first act has a compelling setup, and the second act had me on the edge of my seat wondering how some of the biggest major conflicts would resolve. The game hits its peak at the end of act 2. There's a boss fight with some ridiculous over-the-top spectacle (in a good way), and all of the main character conflicts that I cared about were resolved. 

Then the game keeps going. 
And going. 
And going.

To say the final act is drawn out is a criminal understatement. Every scene is stretched out to its limit, information is constantly repeated because the audience can't be trusted to pay attention, and characters talk in circles. Any scene with [spoiler]Barnabas Tharmr aka Odin[/spoiler] made me want to blow my brains out, and they take up pretty much the entire third act. I really can't stress enough how drawn out the finale of this game is.

I hate to use this word, but FFXVI's narrative is [b]pretentious.[/b] It acts as though it is telling the most grandiose, nuanced, deeply compelling story imaginable, when in reality it is the same gnostic slop we have been presented with for decades at this point. Having [spoiler]"god" actually be a lesser malevolent force[/spoiler] is nothing new to the FF franchise, in fact it's the plot of just about every game in the series. But man if FFXVI doesn't act like this is the first time it's ever been done, and that you should be in awe for it being so avant-garde. For being such a contrived plot, you'd think they would've been able to execute it with precision at least, but FFXVI falls short here as well. The point has been made but my feelings are only so strong because acts 1 and 2 were so promising, which made me feel even more disappointed with the lackluster finale that ultimately ended up being a huge waste of time.

[h2][b]GAMEPLAY[/b][/h2]
[*] Speaking of a huge waste of time, FFXVI's combat is repetitive and boring. You spam basic attacks until your abilities are ready, use said abilities, rinse and repeat for [b]100 HOURS[/b]. Every single enemy is a damage sponge. The combat does actually have a lot of depth in terms of how you can chain combos and abilities, but you are never incentivized to explore this depth, as you will ultimately end up doing less damage than if you had just done the aforementioned "spam square until abilities are off cooldown." I think this repetitiveness could have been remedied by a DMC-style "grading" system that encourages players to actually use combos. Maybe give them a damage boost if combos are executed properly, then it feels like the enemies are sponges for a reason other than to waste your time.


[h1][b][u]TLDR[/u]/FINAL THOUGHTS[/b][h1]
[*] [b]TLDR: [/b]Play something else that interests you and respects your time more. Although FFXVI has some stand-out moments, I cannot recommend it due to its needlessly long playtime, disappointing final act and repetitive gameplay. 

[*] I'm screaming into the void saying this, but please stop making 30-40 hour RPGs 70-100 hours with pointless filler. I miss when FF games were 30-40 hours and told a succinct, compelling story with great characters that stayed with you long after the credits rolled.

I bought FF16 because it was made by the same team as FF14. I LOVE FF14 and would sing its praises to anyone willing to listen. But that praise comes with the acknowledgement that FF14 is an MMO, and the understanding that MMO devs are limited in what they can do when it comes to gameplay and presentation. Despite those limitations, FF14 managed to craft one of the best stories I've ever experienced in gaming.

While I wasn't expecting FF16 to reach the storytelling highs of Shadowbringers or Endwalker, I at least expected it to be fun and tell a good story. The devs somehow managed to fail at both. Horribly.

People describe this game's story as "FF meets Game of Thrones" and that's only true on a surface level. It's dark and gritty with a plot that focuses heavily on politics and intrigue with the occasional kaiju battle mixed in. But the writing fails horribly at making any of it actually interesting or meaningful. Characters are paper thin, with Jill, the female lead, in particular being quite possibly the blandest FF character I've ever seen. Her sole character trait is "Clive's girlfriend" and has so little personality or agency, she may as well just be another accessory hanging off of Clive's belt. The political intrigue is also mostly set dressing, to give Clive a reason to revisit the same brown/grey town for the 10th time, but never actually give the player a reason to care about the wider world or the people in it. Cutscenes and dialogues are presented with bare bones, MMO-style cinematography that works fine for games like FF14 but has no business in a modern single-player RPG. The plot is also predictable as hell, embracing every "dark fantasy" trope in existence with little in the way of surprises or twists. You've seen this story a million times before.

The quest design ranges from boring fetch quests to main storyline quests that involve watching a dozen or so roundabout dialogue scenes before being sent down a linear corridor where you fight a group of the same reskinned enemies with the same shallow combat mechanics.

The combat system itself is pitifully bland at first, then gets fun after you unlock a few more abilities, then gets bland again once you realise those abilities are all flash and no substance. You can easily win any fight by just dodging and hitting things with your sword. The Eikon fights have potential at first, but they feel so janky to control and the fights drag on so long that they don't feel anywhere near as powerful and badass as they should. Not to mention most of them play out more like on-rails shooters and QTE fests than an actual combat system.

Even the character and world design is a letdown. Final Fantasy has a reputation for crafting beautiful worlds that you want to get lost in, with memorable characters whose designs spark the imagination. But I think whoever was in charge of the art in this game forgot what franchise this is, because every environment you visit has the same washed out, grey/brown color palette. Character designs are equally as bland. Clive, for some reason, is the only character who even remotely looks like what you'd expect a FF character to look like. But because everyone else around him looks so painfully drab, he ends up looking like a cosplayer who got sent back in time. It's impossible to take him seriously. And the game really, really, wants you to take him seriously.

If there's one positive, it's in the sound department. The voice acting and music are top notch, but unfortunately neither can save an otherwise excruciatingly dull game.

If I could get a refund, I would.

This game is an embarrassment as a Final Fantasy, an RPG, an action game and a PC port. There is good things here, like crap sprinkled with gold, but overall it gets ruined by under-developed characters, horrible story pacing, horrible side content, mind-numbing combat systems, RPG mechanics that don't matter at all and a terrible PC release that as far as I can tell, has not had a single patch since its release a year ago.

Here's a deeper outline into each of my points:

* In my opinion, the two biggest selling points for a Final Fantasy should be its story, and its gameplay, FFXVI fails at both spectacularly. The story starts strong with a pretty visually impressive prologue and an easily digestible setting. But then the actual game starts, and it feels like to meet a quota on how long FF games should be, they added A LOT of filler that interrupts the pacing of the story to a halt. Save NPCs so they can clear your path, help merchants with random monsters, gather sand in some corner of the map...the list goes on. These are main story quest examples that did not have to be there and have negative impact on the characters, or the story as a whole. 

* Characters are a mixed bag of well built and one dimensional. Most of the main cast is the later, including the main character. Despite having emotional moments for the characters to grow, it doesn't feel believable or impactful in a way that makes them grow. And some of them even die before they get a chance to be explored more, or were some of the few good ones. The decisions of who lives and dies feels arbitrary and sometimes so out of the blue that you question what the point was at all.

* The combat and RPG systems are as deep as a puddle, but also not very wide either. Most of the time you will be spamming one button to do your basic combo and doing your abilities on cooldown, it's not deep, and because there's nothing related to elemental resistances or weaknesses, the only difference between eikon powers is which ones do more damage than stagger, or viceversa. I cleared the whole game with the early set of eikons (Phoenix, Garuda, Titan) and never felt any need to upgrade or even change my abilities, you can roll the game with no thought or planning. The RPG elements like levels and equipment also feel tacked on with no deeper meaning than extra stats or meaningful changes other than increasing damage of skills or reducing cooldowns. It's all incredibly shallow through and through, at least most big boss battles are flashy but more of a spectacle than a challenge.

* Lastly the PC port is absolutely horrendous, a high-end PC should NOT be struggling to keep even a 60 fps lock, the game eats Vram like a mukbang youtuber and you will have to exit back to title to refresh your session, in order to restore performance. It's honestly unacceptable that a year after you still have to use community fixes to make the game bearable, cutscenes locked at 30 fps in a cutscene-heavy game should not be a thing.

I would recommend this game if you want a somewhat okay but ultimately lacking movie game, you will be sitting down through cutscenes more than playing, and even then, the playing won't be too great.

Just not a very good game. Sad to see how far this series has fallen; this is a poor clone of a souls game without any of the heart we're used to from the FF series. 15 was a shitpost of a game that didn't take itself seriously and had some fun as a result; this is whiplash in the other direction and while the tone is improved, the execution is so flubbed this will likely go down as one of the worst entries in the series.

We've gone from vast RPG landscapes of FF7 to cramped, small maps on a small continent. Seriously, the chocobo is laughably slow because if it was any faster an entire map would take you about 15 seconds to traverse. Not that you have to -- the game lets you fast travel basically everywhere. Using the in-game distance calculator the entire continent is about 3km wide. The world is not nearly populated enough for any of its stakes to feel real. It projects a self-importance that its contents do not justify.

The characters are wooden, the plot derivative and the gameplay is frustrating because of non-responsive controls, but also too easy so that the poor controls don't make the game frustrating. The entire second act of the game (about 10-12 hours worth of content) feels like it could be reduced to a 2 minute cutscene and probably improve the pacing -- which is atrocious, with multiple time skips scattered throughout the game. Crafting is super shallow, combat is gimmicky and the side quests are so few, so inconsequential and take so little time to complete you wonder why they even bothered.

I'm too far in to ask for a refund but I just find myself asking "why should I complete this game?" It feels like a chore with no payoff. I don't give a crap what happens to any of these characters.

The pacing of this game is dogshit and I would not have bought it if I had realized that this game took the FF14 approach of time-fillers between genuinely decent story beats. Alas I am unable to refund this game and have to resort to using a review to let off steam.

Two years after release, and over a year since its PC launch, this game still runs terribly on PC. I have a high-end system, and the only titles that give me trouble are ones that are poorly optimized—and unfortunately, this is one of them. I’ve tried every suggested fix and tweak to squeeze out better performance, but it still isn’t where it should be.

On top of inconsistent FPS, there are frequent technical issues. For example, the game has locked up multiple times simply from alt-tabbing.

It’s a great game at its core, but in its current state I can’t recommend it on PC.
